label.text: Smoking
Cigarettes were first readily available to consumers in the early 1900s.
In the 1950s, research studies found that the tar in cigarette smoke caused cancer in mice.
Tobacco companies claimed there was no evidence that smoking caused cancer in humans.

Smoking
Aiman and Nina found two graphs about cigarette smoking and cancer in humans.
This graph shows the death rates (per 100,000 people) from lung cancer of men and women in two different countries (Country 1 and Country 2) since 1950.
This graph shows the sales of cigarettes per person in the same two countries since 1900.
Lung cancer death rates, 1950 to 2020

What did the tobacco companies assume when making this claim?
Humans might consume more tar.
Humans might choose not to smoke.
Humans might inhale other chemicals as well as tar.
Humans might react differently than mice when exposed to tar.
The graphs show data over extended periods.
Which one of these statements is supported by the graphs?
All men who purchased cigarettes developed lung cancer.
The peak in lung cancer death rates occurred at the same time as the peak in cigarette sales.
Lung cancer death rates tend to decrease following a decline in cigarette sales.
There were no deaths of women from lung cancer in Country 1 before 2000.
As well as being linked to cancer, tobacco smoking is a risk factor for several diseases that affect the respiratory system.
Which of the following factors directly increase the risk of respiratory disease?
Select Yes or No for each factor.
frequent hand washing
air pollution
good water quality
Various methods can be used to influence people to stop smoking.
Which one of the following ways of influencing people to stop smoking is based on the use of technology?
Ban smoking in public areas such as restaurants and offices.
Increase the cost of cigarettes.
Support people to quit smoking.
Produce nicotine patches to help people give up cigarettes.
Which one of the following statements is supported by the graphs?
In 2020, men in Country 2 had a higher rate of smoking than men in Country 1.
In 2020, women in Country 1 had a higher rate of smoking than women in Country 2.
In 2020 in Country 1, the rate of smoking among men was decreasing, and the rate of smoking among women was increasing.
In 2020 in Country 2, the rate of smoking among men was increasing, and the rate of smoking among women was decreasing.
